thread.title: London close: Stocks end slightly lower as commodities provide drag
thread.title_full: London close: Stocks end slightly lower as commodities provide drag

title: London close: Stocks end slightly lower as commodities provide drag
text:
245.00 +1.00 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - London stocks finished in the red on Tuesday as oil and commodity producers provided a drag on the market. BP and Royal Dutch Shell (Xetra: R6C1.DE - news ) declined as Brent's October contract began weekly proceedings below $50. The slump in oil came as data showed Japan's economy contracted and US producers added drilling rigs despite a recent slump in the industry. BG Group (LSE: BG.L - news ) and Weir Group , which provide engineering services to the oil sector, also slipped. 
Mining giant Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) dipped after the Daily Telegraph reported that activist investor Harris Associates has built a £250m position in the world's largest commodities trader. 
On a positive note for the market, China fixed its yuan exchange rate slightly higher for the second day running. 
In another boost to stocks, US house-builder confidence hit the highest level in almost a decade in August, according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo (Hanover: NWT.HA - news ) . The housing market index rose 1 point to 61, reaching its highest level since November 2005, compared with analysts' expectations for a 59 reading. 
Elsewhere in the US, a widely-followed index of the manufacturing sentiment in the New York area plunged to its worst level since the recession in August. According to the New York Federal Reserve, the Empire State general business conditions index plummeted to -14.9 from 3.9 in July, way below analysts' expectations for a 4.5 reading. 
Looking ahead, UK inflation figure are due on Tuesday with analysts expecting a pick-up in growth in July of 0.9% year-on-year compared to 0.8% the previous month. 
While inflation remains well below the Bank of England's target of 2%, one of the central bank's policymakers said waiting too long to lift rates could hurt the UK's economic recovery. 
Wring in the Daily Telegraph, Kristen Forbes said rates need to be increased "well before" inflation reaches the BoE (Shenzhen: 200725.SZ - news ) 's target. 
"Maintaining interest rates at the current low levels during an expansion risks creating distortions," she wrote in an article for Monday's paper, published online on Sunday. 
On the corporate front, Wolseley (LSE: WOS.L - news ) was a top riser after Citi raised its rating on the plumbing and heating products provider to 'buy' from 'neutral', saying the company was well-position to deliver strong earnings growth over the medium term. 
Bovis Homes (LSE: BVS.L - news ) slumped despite posting a 9% rise in first-half pre-tax profit as it reported a record number of legal completions and said it's on track to deliver its expected volume of new homes for 2015. 
Rightmove (LSE: RMV.L - news ) figures on Sunday showed UK house prices fell 0.8% month-on-month in August, following a 0.1% increase a month earlier. 
Shire (Xetra: S7E.DE - news ) was lower on news it is likely to improve its takeover offer for US competitor Baxalta (Berlin: 9BX.BE - news ) after its first offer was rebuffed, but has put pressure on its rival to make some concessions first. The Dublin-headquartered pharmaceuticals group will have to add around $5 per share to its initial $45.23 all-share offer for Baxalta, sources told various Sunday newspapers. 
Inmarsat (Other OTC: IMASF - news ) advanced after confirming that the launch of its third satellite in the Global Express programme, I-5 F3, has been scheduled at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Friday 28 August. 
TUI AG (LSE: TUI.L - news ) climbed after The Times reported that the travel company is considering spinning off non-mainstream assets.
